title: 115_hr3717
content: The Small Business Owners' Tax Simplification Act of 2017 may be cited as such. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The Small Business Owners' Tax Simplification Act of 2017 includes provisions for quarterly reporting of estimated tax payments, aligning filing thresholds for information reporting, electronic signature standards, pre-notification testing, cafeteria plan treatment, exclusion of certain self-employment income, deduction for health insurance costs, and worker classification rules. The Small Business Owners' Tax Simplification Act of 2017 includes amendments to quarterly reporting of estimated tax payments, changing deadlines to July 15 and October 15. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2017. Additionally, the act aligns filing thresholds for information reporting. The Small Business Owners' Tax Simplification Act of 2017 amends the dollar threshold for filing a 1099-MISC from $600 to $1,500, with an inflation adjustment provision for taxable years after 2018. The Small Business Owners' Tax Simplification Act of 2017 increases the dollar threshold for filing a 1099-MISC from $600 to $1,500, with a provision for rounding amounts to the nearest multiple of $100. Additionally, the heading of subsection (a) of section 6041 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to "Payments Exceeding Threshold." The Small Business Owners' Tax Simplification Act of 2017 increases the dollar threshold for filing a 1099-MISC from $600 to $1,500, with rounding to the nearest multiple of $100. Subsection (e) of section 6050W is amended to eliminate the transaction threshold for reporting under subsection (a)(2). The amendments increase the dollar threshold for filing a 1099-MISC and eliminate the transaction threshold for reporting under subsection (a)(2). Effective after December 31, 2017. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish uniform standards for electronic signatures for disclosure authorizations related to taxpayer returns and power of attorney within 6 months of enactment. Additionally, pre-notification testing will be implemented. SEC. 5. PRE-NOTIFICATION TESTING. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct prenotification testing within 180 days of this Act to verify recipient information for tax refunds transferred electronically. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include self-employed individuals in qualified benefits under a cafeteria plan of an eligible employer. This applies to individuals who are employees under section 401(c)(1) and those treated as partners under section 1372(a). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include self-employed individuals in qualified benefits under a cafeteria plan of an eligible employer. An individual who owns an unincorporated trade or business is treated as their own employer. A partnership is treated as the employer of each partner who is an employee. Amounts excluded from earned income cannot exceed the individual's earned income derived from the business. The cafeteria plan applies to self-employed individuals and partners in a partnership. Partners treated as employees have their wages from the S corporation considered earned income. The Secretary may make adjustments as needed. Deductions or benefits cannot be doubled. No deduction or credit allowed for amounts excluded from gross income under certain sections. Amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code for Simple Cafeteria Plans, providing an alternative for certain plans with specific requirements met through employer contributions. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2017, regarding employer contributions to qualified benefits under the plan. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to adjust the minimum amount required for Social Security quarters of coverage. SEC. 8 allows a deduction for certain health insurance costs for self-employment tax purposes. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9 amends the Internal Revenue Code to address worker classification in voluntary withholding agreements. SEC. 10 discusses the impact of voluntary training and group discount programs on worker classification. SEC. 7706 states that worker classification should not consider voluntary training or discounts on goods and services. The Secretary will issue necessary regulations for this section. Effect of voluntary training and group discount programs on worker classification is addressed in Sec. 7706. The Secretary will issue regulations for this section.
